qas.question: How did the Greeks look upon their forebears ?

answers.text: Greeks of classical antiquity idealized their Mycenaean ancestors

qas.question: How did they believe their forebears lived ?

answers.text: Mycenaean period as a glorious era of heroes, closeness of the gods and material wealth

qas.question: What literary events were believed to be a fact of truth ?

answers.text: The Homeric Epics (i.e. Iliad and Odyssey) were especially and generally accepted as part of the Greek past

qas.question: Who was the author of these tales ?

plausible_answers.text: a glorious era of heroes, closeness of the gods and material wealth

context: The <a0_0>Greeks of classical antiquity <b10_0><b15_0>idealized their Mycenaean ancestors<b15_0/><b10_0/><a0_0/> and the <a1_0><b11_0><b16_0>Mycenaean period as <b5_0>a glorious era of heroes, closeness of the gods and material wealth<b16_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>.<b11_0/> <a2_0><b12_0><b17_0>The Homeric Epics<b17_0/> (i.e. <b6_0>Iliad and Odyssey<b6_0/>) were especially and generally accepted as part of the Greek past<b12_0/><a2_0/> and it was not until the <b7_0>19th century<b7_0/> that scholars began to question <a3_0><b13_0><b18_0>Homer<b18_0/><b13_0/><a3_0/>'s historicity. As part of the Mycenaean heritage that survived, the names of the gods and goddesses of Mycenaean Greece (e.g. <a4_0><b9_0><b14_0><b19_0>Zeus<b9_0/>, Poseidon and <b8_0>Hades<b19_0/><b14_0/><b8_0/><a4_0/>) became major figures of the Olympian Pantheon of later antiquity.
